Title.evidence: This randomized controlled trial evaluated echocardiographic data from the Placement of Aortic Transcatheter Valves (PARTNER) 1 Trial.

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized to TAVR or surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) in PARTNER 1A (TAVR, n=321; SAVR, n=313) and TAVR or medical treatment in PARTNER 1B (TAVR, n=165).

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included severe aortic stenosis, and the study was conducted across multiple centers.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized to TAVR or surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) in PARTNER 1A (TAVR, n=321; SAVR, n=313) and TAVR or medical treatment in PARTNER 1B (TAVR, n=165).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was death or reintervention for aortic valve structural indications, assessed over a median follow-up of 3.1 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomized to TAVR or surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) in PARTNER 1A (TAVR, n=321; SAVR, n=313) and TAVR or medical treatment in PARTNER 1B (TAVR, n=165).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of 2795 patients (mean age 84.5 years, 47% female), 424 TAVR and 49 SAVR patients had 5-year echocardiogram data.

Result_Outcome.evidence: TAVR showed early favorable hemodynamic changes, with a decrease of −2.9 mm Hg in aortic valve mean gradient, an increase of 0.028 in Doppler velocity index, and an increase of 0.09 cm² in effective orifice area, with stability over time.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
